newsitem.title: UK: UK Labour criticises small-firm job law opt-out.
newsitem.headline: UK Labour criticises small-firm job law opt-out.

text.p: The government's plans to exempt small firms from the law on unfair dismissals as part of a new drive to cut red tape and boost Britain's competitiveness could itself be anti-competitive, the Labour party said on Monday.
The opposition party's education and employment spokesman, David Blunkett, said the proposals could encourage some companies to break into smaller units to be designated as small firms.
"A basic entitlement for employees should not depend on the size of the company, but on a basic set of minimum standards for all individuals," Blunkett said in a statement.

He was responding to an announcement by the government that it will consult on a recommendation by its Deregulation Task Force that small firms should be exempted from the jurisdiction of industrial tribunals in respect of unfair dismissal legislation for new employees.
The government said it would consider whether some other provision, such as an extended qualifying period for new employees in small firms, would be appropriate.
The proposed change would not affect current employees or extend to other grounds for access to industrial tribunals.
Other deregulation initiatives, announced by Deputy Prime Minister Michael Heseltine at a news conference, include:

-- Repealing the Trustee Investments Act by a deregulation order this autumn. This will save charitable trusts at least 40 million stg a year by removing restrictions on where they can invest for the best retruns.
-- Cutting the number of government surveys and statistical forms, saving industry 17.5 million stg a year by the end of the decade.
But the government rejected a recommendation that it delay implementation of new regulations covering activity centres.

It also said it would go ahead with consultations on whether to regulate the private security industry, contrary to the panel's advice that any public concerns could be met by imposing a new legal duty on employers not to hire convicted criminals.
